reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: The exams are hard, but I absolutely love him. He's a master of reducing down topics and makes fantastic visuals. He writes his own text book (which he gives you) so he knows the content inside and out. Lots of detailed examples and demos. Homeworks are the perfect length, interesting, and on topic. Easy recommendation.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He is a nice professor but not a good exam maker. His exam focus too much on tiny details and takes away a lot of points. I took both 382 and 392, and the exam was hard asf. Based on what he said this is the third year he teach. I was told 382 exam average 2022 was 36 , 2023 was 46 or 56, so do work hard for exam

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: This course is extremely challenging, be prepared to read the textbook beforehand, else you are probably going to be really lost. The exams are extremely difficult, you can expect to spend a lot of time doing practice questions on your own if you wish to do well on the exams. For your reference, the course average for most exams are in the 60-70s.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He does not accept any late work no matter what. Lectures are really great and homework assignments are always interesting. In every lecture, he gives out hints on the content of midterms and final. He is very friendly and is impressed by doing hws with recursion.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: If you're a CySec major, you're really going to be going through it when you take this class. On top of 334 and 385, 382 will be the most laborious. I managed to get 100s on most of the homework/labs, but I allocated more hours than I should have for this class. The grading certainly doesn't help, since 36% was the average for the first exam.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Professor Hao is a great lecturer but the course had a rough start. It had harsh grading procedures and a lack of rubrics. The first midterm had 75% of the class get below a 60, but the class turned around after the first half. He is a great lecturer and changed a lot over the semester. The class was loads of fun after he changed. High workload!

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Shudong is MUCH better in 392, but it's also a better course. He gives you everything you need to do the homework assignments. They all felt fair except for std392io and midterm 2. I enjoyed him and the lectures. If you don't get a 100 on an assignment, no extra credit for it. Very knowledgeable, but still learning how to be a good professor.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He is highly unprofessional. Reading the textbook is a MUST, but it probably won't help you very much on the tests. The homework and the labs do not really relate to what we are learning in class, and honestly some of the assembly ones just feel like busy work. Do not recommend.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He is condescending to his students and expects you to know everything by heart after saying things one time. His grading may not be too harsh but it is often wrong.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Every question on Shudong's exams are straight out of his textbook, so just pay attention and read and you'll be fine. Learned a lot in this course, and despite being quite harsh with credit on certain assignments, he is a good professor.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He's honestly an awesome professor! All you needed to do was either pay attention during lectures or watch the lecture recordings and take notes. He goes out of his way to connect with students and provide help when we ask for it. He also listens to course feedback and curves the class. You may have to email him a few times about misgraded work.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: He expects you to know the material from heart and more after he is done teaching it. For labs little to nothing to do with the actual things you learn in the class. makes you write assembly code of things that would be ten times easier to code in c++, java, or python like merge sort. Class and labs does not relate to each other around the week 5.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Shudong is honestly an amazing teacher if you pay attention in lecture. I was learning a lot in the beginning, but then I stopped paying attention after a certain point and I was just so lost. Very heavy on homework and labs. Only bad thing is that grading is not consistent. There is a lot of bad grading but if you email him, he will fix it.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Has a real in-depth understanding of the course and is equipped to answer a wide arrange of questions. He's pretty unforgiving in terms of late assignments or any requests for extensions. Very available outside of class for help in terms of emails and office hours and overall shows that he cares about helping and getting to know the student.

reviews.department: Professor in the Computer Science department at Stevens Institute of Technology
reviews.review: Labs and non-written homework assignments, which is most of the work, is just barely related to the course material, and really hurts when it leaves us barely knowing what to answer on the tests. Said labs and programming assignments are a struggle for students, and due dates are so close to each other that received help is minimal.
